item.title: Are flying robots the perfect co-workers?
item.description: The year is 2020. A group of warehouse workers are locking up for the weekend.
item.ExtractedText: 1 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend Drone Scan is a device attached to a drone and used to scan barcodes. The drones can fly up and down the isles and do the inventory which is traditionally done by men using ladders, forklifts and handheld scanners. Co-founder Jasper Pons says he thinks warehouse workers will love their new assistants. "They are going to say: 'give us the drones and give us back our weekends'." Hide Caption 2 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend It has a patented indoor navigation system which tracks where it is in the warehouse by measuring its distance from the ground and walls, so when it scans a barcode it can automatically update the records with the exact location of that product. Hide Caption 3 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend The founders have big plans for the device. "Eventually you will have the drones working away in the warehouses at night when everybody is asleep, as a real drone, as the name suggest," says Craig Leppan, co-founder of Drone Scan, pictured. Hide Caption 4 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend The technology has potential to improve efficiency for large delivery giants such as Amazon. The forklift pictured at this Amazon warehouse in France, for example, could become a thing of the past. Hide Caption 5 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend The idea came when using a homemade drone to map fishing grounds. Since setting up the company in 2013, the founders have gone from using a smaller drone, pictured, to a larger and more advanced model. Hide Caption 6 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend The drone they use today is called DJI Matrice and is designed for commercial purposes, and allows for users to attach other devices to the drone and link it up to a central system, hence its industrial look in comparison to consumer drones, such as the one on this picture. Hide Caption 7 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend For the time being, the drones require a person controlling them with a joystick-like device. The plan, however, is for autonomous drones to take over the inventory in as little time as one year. Hide Caption 8 of 9 9 photos: The robots that could give you back your weekend The drones could change how warehouses are built. "We've heard from people who are thinking about designing new warehouses which are drone friendly," Leppan says. Hide Caption
